picture_list.caption: Most works by renowned artist and environmentalist Andy Goldsworthy are made from impermanent materials, like leaves and snow, and are only experienced through photographs documenting the works' brief existence. But the Storm King Art Center in New Windsor, New York, is home to one of Goldsworthy's permanent structures: a long, snaking stone wall named "Five Men, Seventeen Days, Fifteen Boulders, One Wall." The wall is one of the most popular pieces at the center, which is home to over 100 sculptures. Explore more photos through the blue location link above, and by searching the  hashtag. Photo by

The Philippine Tarsier Sanctuary in Corella, Bohol, is owned by the non-profit Philippine Tarsier Foundation, whose mission is to save the tarsiers. The Sanctuary gives visitors the opportunity to see these tiny tarsiers up close, learn more about the species and take photographs of them as they live freely inside a protected forest.

Tarsiers, one of the smallest primates, have thrived in rainforests around the world for the past 45 million years; however, the tarsier population has drastically dwindled since the 1960s as a result of habitat loss, hunting, pesticides and human disturbance. Once a common sight on the Philippine island of Bohol, the tarsier is now on the endangered species list. To see more photos of the wide-eyed tarsier tap on the blue location link above. Featured photo by

In 2011, Rob Lutter () said goodbye to his family, friends and life in London and set off on a 30,000 km cycling tour around the world. He took only a tent, bike, SLR camera and iPhone as he biked from continental Europe to the Middle East, over the Himalayas, and across the deserts of Western China. During the hardest parts of his journey, Rob says the Instagram community helped him make it through. "The support from people around the world was incredible. Messages of encouragement would arrive every other day and there were times when I'd cycle longer and further just to reach a town in an attempt to get some Wi-Fi, to connect to Instagram! It became a positive obsession of mine." Two years into his journey, Rob has cycled over 15,000 km, crossed 21 borders, and arrived in Hong Kong, where he is now preparing for the next leg of his trip in Australia. To tune into the rest of the journey, be sure to follow him on Instagram  and visit his website: thelifecycle.net.

In New York's Times Square sits "Heartwalk," a heart-shaped sculpture built out of boardwalk salvaged from the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy. Heartwalk was conceived, designed and constructed by Brooklyn-based , and was the winner of 's fifth annual Square Valentine Heart Design challenge. See more making-of photos at  and browse Heartwalk photos at the  hashtag. Photo by .

On the first Saturday of every March, approximately fifty mushers and their teams of sled dogs gather in Anchorage, Alaska, to kick off the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race. The race takes competitors on a more than 1,100 mile journey across Alaska—from Anchorage in the south to the remote city of Nome along the state's western coast—and exposes competitors to the most extreme weather Alaska has to offer. To see more photos from the Iditarod, browse the  hashtag. Photo by
Every Sunday we post a weekly roundup on our blog (blog.instagram.com), featuring some of our favorite photos from the week. Congrats to those whose photos are featured this week!

Minneapolis-based illustrator and art director David Schwen () has long used Instagram as a creative outlet, documenting unique typography, literally interpreting common turns of phrase, and adding notification badges to everyday objects. But lately, Schwen has embarked on a new theme: through the hashtag , he has recreated paired Pantone color swatches with commonly paired food items. Check out  to see the rest of David's  and follow along to see what he dreams up next!

We were very excited to host street artist  at Instagram HQ today! Instagram gives JR a way to connect with the people who see his work every day. He showed us a photo of one of his pieces on a building in Los Angeles and how his followers left comments like "That's the view from my office!" He oftentimes comments back at his fans asking them to show him their view of his work.

Be sure to check out his account for behind-the-scenes peeks at the latest installations of his massive, flyposted black-and-white photos.

Weekend Hashtag Project: 

Today marks the one-year anniversary since we began sharing fantastic user stories, incredible location features, behind-the-scenes looks at the Instagram team and more through our official Instagram account! In honor of this milestone, the goal this weekend is to recreate your very first Instagram photo.
For our example, we took the photo on the top exactly one year ago when Instagram team members , , and  were all working away at a café in San Francisco. We headed back there to take the new and improved photo on the bottom, and it brought back a lot of memories. We hope this project will for you, too!

PROJECT RULES: Please only add the hashtag to photos taken over this weekend and only submit your own photographs to the project. Any image taken then tagged over the weekend is eligible to be featured on the Instagram blog at blog.instagram.com on Monday morning!

Moscow (Москва) is known for its extravagance: it's the most expensive city in the world, home to the most billionaires, the costliest cups of coffee and—opening in the next few months—the biggest building in Europe. But the Russian capital is also experiencing a creative explosion, evident in the growing number of talented Instagrammers from the city.

Want to see Moscow for yourself? We’ve gathered together a group of exceptional Instagrammers who are snapping pictures from the heart of it all. Be sure to follow them at:  (photo featured here), , , and .

In honor of the Instagram community growing to 100 million people actively sharing their lives through photos each month, we asked you to tell us your Instagram stories through the hashtag . We were humbled and overwhelmed by all of your submissions, and we wish there were a way to showcase every one of the many messages we loved. Be sure to read more about what Instagram means to , , , , , ,  and —whose photos are featured above—in addition to several other stories we've highlighted over at blog.instagram.com.

The Welsh National Assembly (Cynulliad Cenedlaethol Cymru) in Cardiff, Wales, houses the legislative body of Welsh government. The building itself, known as the Senedd, was designed by architect Richard Rogers as an energy-efficient building seated directly on the waters of Cardiff Bay. The building features a distinctive undulating ceiling and large central “funnel” made of Welsh red cedar and over 1,000 tons of Welsh slate floors. Under the funnel lies a public viewing gallery from which the public can watch the proceedings of the 60 Assembly Members as they debate.
See more photos from the Senate at blog.instagram.com and by tapping the blue location name above. Photo by

Baseball fans, rejoice! Spring training is here. Starting every February, Major League Baseball () runs a six-week series of practices and exhibition games as a warm up to the regular season. Crowds flock to the games in Arizona and Florida to bask in warm weather and get a first look at their favorite teams.
Be sure to follow all the spring training action on Instagram via the hashtag  and your favorite teams's account on Instagram (try , ,  and  to start!). You can also tap the blue location text above this image to see photos from the Detroit Tigers () spring stadium. Photo by .

Tens of thousands gathered today in Vatican City's Piazza San Pietro (St. Peter's Square) to bid farewell to Pope Benedict XVI as he gave his final general audience. He was escorted through the crowd in his open-sided Popemobile to greet attendees before ascending to the balcony of St. Peter's Basilica to present his final address. The pope announced his resignation two weeks ago, citing poor health as the reason for leaving the papal office. Pope Benedict XVI is the first pope to step down in nearly 600 years.
The pope will officially leave office tomorrow, leaving the papacy vacant until the cardinals emerge from the sequestered election process known as conclave to announce who has been selected as the 266th pope. Photo by

David Guttenfelder (), the Associated Press Chief Photographer for Asia, is one of the first people to ever post Instagram photos from within the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK). Most visitors to the DPRK don’t have access to internet and—until just a few weeks ago—foreigners were not allowed to bring mobile phones into the country. Now David can share personal iPhone and iPod Touch photos to Instagram as he captures them. “There are so many curious, strangely beautiful, or melancholy details around us here,” he says. “These might not be typical of the news photos I usually transmit, but they offer fleeting glimpses of this country, and how it feels to be here.” To see more photos from the DPRK, be sure to follow  on Instagram and tap the blue location text above this image.

Today, we're excited to announce that there are currently 100,000,000 active users on Instagram. You read that number right—one hundred million people use Instagram every month! We want to take this opportunity to thank every one of you for making this community such an incredible place full of creativity, support and openness. Instagram has always been a fast, beautiful and fun way to share your photos with friends and family, and you have helped make it so much more.
This isn't just a milestone for us as a company, but one for the entire Instagram community. In honor of this, we want to hear your stories. Share your photos of what Instagram means to you and tag them  so we can hear your voices. We'll feature some of our favorite photos right here on our account.

From our team to the hundred million people who call Instagram home, we say thank you.

Happy Monday, Instagram! For today's  we have the pleasure of introducing the Internet's most handsome and well-dressed shiba inu, . Follow along to add some fluff to your feed while keeping current on the latest fashions!

This year, February 25th marks the full moon of the third lunar month, a day observed by Buddhists throughout the world as Magha Puja. The day celebrates a series of auspicious events in the life of the Buddha, which culminated in an important teaching that laid the foundations of Buddhism. The observance of this day varies by region, but can include candlelight processions, pagoda festivals and meditations. To see more photos, browse the  hashtag, or click the blue location link above. Photo by .

On the 15th day of the lunar new year, countries throughout Asia mark the end of lunar new year festivities by lighting elaborate paper lanterns. These festivals mark the first full moon of the lunar new year, and while their exact origin is unknown, releasing lanterns typically symbolizes letting go of the past and embracing the new year. The day also serves to build community and goodwill within and between families. To see more photos, browse the  and click the blue location link above! Photo by .

Weekend Hashtag Project: 

We’ve all seen trees that have been blown into unique shapes, bending with the wind, but have you ever thought to use these trees as props? One of our favorite Chicago storytellers  has done just that with his “Lean With It” hashtag collection! The goal this weekend is to capture photographs of people standing next to and leaning in the same direction as unique or oddly shaped trees.

PROJECT RULES: Please only add the hashtag to photos taken over this weekend and only submit your own photographs to the project. Any image taken then tagged over the weekend is eligible to be featured on the Instagram blog at blog.instagram.com on Monday morning! Featured photo by .

If you ever visit Prague, the famous Nationale-Nederlanden building, nicknamed Dancing House (Tančící dům) or “Fred and Ginger,” is hard to miss. It sits in the middle of a densely built section of Prague, surrounded by other structures that are nearly all the city's standard Baroque or Art Nouveau styles. See more photos of Croatian-Czech architect Vlado Milunić and Canadian-American architect Frank Gehry's quirky architectural marvel by tapping on the blue location text above this image! Photo by .

In the heart of Brooklyn, woodworker Ariele Alasko () builds custom furniture out of repurposed materials and shares the process on Instagram. "I love being able to share my building process in a quick moment without having to really stop what I'm doing," she says. "Instagram has been a great way to feel connected to the outside world while I'm holed up in my shop, and it gives me a reason to document and share things that I may not have otherwise." Want to see more of Ariele's work? Be sure to follow along on Instagram: .

The Prague Astronomical Clock, or Pražský Orloj, is a medieval clock mounted on the southern wall of Prague's Old Town City Hall. Despite being the world's oldest working astronomical clock, the Pražský Orloj still provides an overwhelming amount of information. This sophisticated clock’s dials, hands and markings display the times of sunrise and sunset, moonrise and moonset, the height of the sun at midday, the times of the solstices and equinoxes, how the Sun moves through the zodiac and how the Moon and the Sun move in the sky above them. It also tells the time—in three different ways!

The Orloj is a beautiful and intricate representation of the human desire to understand and explore the heavens. To see more photographs of this truly amazing clock tap on the blue location text above this image. Photo by .

"Levitation is like philosophy. It's not just a jump shot; it is a floating moment," says , an economist and philosopher living in Jakarta, Indonesia. Junanto, an avid traveler, likes to document his trips by taking photos that make him appear to levitate. He shared his process for capturing these photos on the Instagram blog, at blog.instagram.com. Check out more of his photos there, or by following .

Happy Monday, Instagrammers! Today's  is almost like getting two fluffs for the price of one! Meet Venus, , a 3-year-old half-tortoiseshell, half-orange tabby, with two different colored eyes. Follow 's adventures to add something truly unique to your feed!

Today, we’re celebrating George Washington’s birthday with an ode to Mount Rushmore. The iconic monument in Keystone, South Dakota, features 60-foot (18 meter) granite busts of Washington and fellow US presidents Thomas Jefferson, Theodore Roosevelt, and Abraham Lincoln. A South Dakota historian named Doane Robinson is credited with the idea for Mount Rushmore to promote tourism in the Black Hills region of the state. The initial plan was to depict each president head to waist, but in 1941, after 14 years of construction, federal funding ran out and the project was forced to end prematurely.

Want to see more? Tap the blue location text above this image. Photo by

In northwest India, seven miles outside the city of Jaipur, the stunning Amer Fort overlooks Maota Lake from atop a forested hill. Visitors to the 400-year-old fort can ride elephants up a zigzagging path to reach the entrance. Inside, there are four main courtyards, one of which contains an elaborate room of mirrors called the Sheesh Mahal.

To explore all the details of the Amer Fort, be sure to tap the blue location text above this image. Photo by .

On the tiny island of Naoshima in the Seto Inland Sea of southern Japan, artist Yayoi Kusama’s “Pumpkin” (1994-2005) sits patiently at the water’s edge. Instagrammers flock to the sleepy island to see its world-class art collection. Kusama’s “Pumpkin” is perhaps the most photogenic artwork on the island, beckoning visitors to come closer and pose with the giant spotted squash that represents Kusama's alter-ego.

Want to see more? Tap the location text above this image. Photo by
Today, we were treated to a visit from NYC Instagrammer ! Check out Chris's feed for serene shots of the Big Apple and portraits of other members of the New York City Instagram community.

Earlier this week we asked you to think outside of the chocolate box and launched a special Valentine's Day Hashtag Project, , which asked people to take photos of the objects that mean the most in their lives. The goal was to capture the heartfelt stories and memories that lie behind these objects and share the various forms of love that they represent to us. Be sure to check out a few of our favorite submissions by , , , , , , , and !

Each year on February 14th, millions of people around the world celebrate Valentine's Day by reaffirming their love and affection for others in their lives. Whether it's a match made on Instagram, or people sharing the meaning behind treasured , the Instagram community is brimming with love. Don't be afraid to share the love! Post a photograph of someone—or something—meaningful in your life on Instagram today! Photo by .

Priya () knows buildings. As part of the architectural team on multiple projects around the world, including the new west-coast flagship Apple Store in Palo Alto, California, this San Francisco designer's experience and passion directs her eye. "Even if the photo isn't of an architecturally significant building, I still think like an architect and find alignments, balance and proportions that speak to me—or at least I try," she explains. Her eye for spatial relations extends even to the dinner table: Priya is also the creator of the  hashtag, where she documents her and her husband's long-standing ritual of making Sunday brunch together.

Imagine what it would be like to live inside of a rainbow. That is exactly what Icelandic artist Olafur Eliasson has created in his rooftop installation, “Your rainbow panorama.” Positioned atop ARoS Aarhus Kunstmuseum, a 10-story art museum located in Århus, Denmark, the walkway yields a spectacular 360-degree view of the city. You can view more vibrant photos from the elevated rainbow installation by tapping the blue location text above this image and visiting the  hashtag. Photos by , , , , and .

Did you know that portrait photography has existed since the invention of the camera? While those classic portraits focused on the subject’s face, modern photographers like Emily Call () are breaking from tradition. By simply hiding her subject behind or underneath objects, she’s added a unique twist to portrait photography. Be sure to view the fruits of Emily’s delightful labor at !

Instagrammers around the world are sharing scenes from this week's Carnival festivities. In cities across Brazil, samba schools spend the four days leading up to Ash Wednesday competing in parades that can last for hours. In Trinidad and Tobago, Carnival is the country's biggest event of the year—it's said that if the islanders are not celebrating Carnival, then they are preparing for it! In Venice, masked baroque revelers march through historic streets and dance at the Gran Ballo delle Maschere.

Want to see more Carnival photos? Tap the location text above this image. Photo by

Happy Monday, Instagrammers! It's time for the ! This week, we're pausing for a moment to head to New York City, where earlier today 2,721 dogs and thousands of adoring dog enthusiasts gathered for the 137th Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show. For the competition, which concludes tomorrow night, 187 breeds are judged across seven different groups, with the "Best in Show" chosen from among the seven group winners. To see more pups, browse the  and  hashtags or click the blue location link above. Photo by .

A snowstorm hit the northeastern United States and parts of Canada this past weekend. Cities along the eastern seaboard saw hurricane-force winds and up to three feet of snow, resulting in power outages and traffic bans throughout the region. Though blizzards don't normally receive names, The Weather Channel decided to highlight this one with a name—Nemo—to mark its significance. View more photos from this past weekend's storm by searching the  and  hashtags. Photo above by .

Valentine's Day is this week, and you know what that means—feeds filled with photos representing love of all kinds, shapes, and sizes. Many will be celebrating love for a significant other, family member, or close friend, but before the holiday arrives we want you to take a moment and think outside of the chocolate box. For the upcoming Valentine's Day holiday, we're giving you an extra hashtag project: .

The goal is to tell the stories of different kinds of love behind the objects we treasure. To get started, try rummaging through your family heirlooms, or think about the objects that you could never live without, then consider what makes them so special and share the love! Check out 's photo above of her first record player and favorite record to get an idea of what we're looking for. We'll be featuring our favorite stories on Valentine's Day!

Starting today, more than 1.5 billion people around the world will celebrate the Lunar New Year—a time for gathering with family, honoring ancestors, and eating! The holiday is celebrated at the beginning of the year in locations that utilize the lunar calendar, and this year marks the Year of the Snake, one of the 12 animals in the Chinese zodiac.
Instagrammers are sharing photos from the 2013 festivities, including traditions like giving children lucky money in red envelopes, hanging lanterns, setting off fireworks, and performing the iconic dragon and lion dances. We've even got some balloons up in our office! To catch a glimpse into today’s festivities, be sure to browse through the , , , and  hashtags. Photo by .

Thursday marked the start of Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week () in New York, where people from all corners of the fashion industry gather to showcase months of sketching, sewing, and planning for their Fall 2013 collections. To scoop the latest fashions, be sure to browse photos at the Mercedes-Benz New York Fashion Week by tapping the blue location text above this image and visit the  and  hashtags. Featured photo by .

Weekend Hashtag Project: 

Every year on February 10 an unusual “holiday” occurs in honor of an object that keeps us dry when it rains and protected from the sun—the umbrella! In honor of Umbrella Day the goal this weekend is to capture photographs of parasols or umbrellas. Channel the classic film “Singin’ in the Rain,” or your inner Mary Poppins, and have fun incorporating this versatile prop into your photos!

PROJECT RULES: Please only add the hashtag to photos taken over this weekend and only submit your own photographs to the project. Any image taken then tagged over the weekend is eligible to be featured on the Instagram blog at
blog.instagram.com on Monday morning! Featured photo by .

Next week, Catholics the world over will recognize Ash Wednesday, the first day of a six-week-long period of fasting and prayer known as Lent. Around the world, the period before Lent is called Carnival and is marked by massive celebrations and parades. But in Louisiana, it's called Mardi Gras. While the culmination of Mardi Gras season occurs on Fat Tuesday—the day before Ash Wednesday—the parades and festivities actually begin several weeks beforehand. To see photos from this year's festivities, search the  hashtag and follow . Laissez les bons temps rouler! Photo by .

The city of Sapporo in northern Japan has hosted its weeklong snow festival every year since 1950. The first festival had only six participants––local high school students who built six modest snow statues in Odori Park. Now, millions of people visit the festival to view over 200 elaborate snow statues and ice sculptures. Often the statues depict notable events, places or people from the previous year.
Want to see this year's sculptures? Be sure to tap the blue location text above this image. Photo by

Last May, Geffen Refaeli, a freelance illustrator in Tel Aviv, Israel, uploaded her very first . The concept: select elements from different pictures appearing in her photo stream and combine them into a doodle! "I take screen shots of the photos in which I find some object or situation that intrigues me and I collect them during the day. I usually start to see a link in my mind between the images, and start to build a story." Follow along as Geffen reinterprets her Instagram feed at . This doodle was inspired by  & .

To learn more about your Instagram feed on the web, check out blog.instagram.com
Another Monday, another ! Today, we go all the way to Nagoya, Japan, to meet , a Holland Lop bunny rabbit named Boo. If you could use a little more floppy-eared fluff in your Instagram feed, follow !

Chiang Mai, Thailand, hosted its annual Flower Festival over the weekend. The city’s public gardens are especially beautiful this time of year, and visitors flock to the gardens to see flowers found only in Chiang Mai. The Flower Festival Parade on Saturday is the highlight every year. Traditional Thai dancers and Miss Chiang Mai Flower Festival competitors ride atop elaborately decorated floral floats and hand out roses to spectators. Want to see more photos? Visit the hashtags  and . Photo by

Today, New Yorkers are celebrating the 100th birthday of Grand Central Station in style with notable speakers, exhibits on the station’s history and even a cake replica of the station’s iconic four-faced clock. The Beaux-Arts terminal was completed in 1913 and was declared a city landmark in 1968 after nearly being razed. As many as 750,000 travelers pass through Grand Central each day, with many visiting just to photograph the mural of constellations spanning the ceiling or explore the secret “whispering gallery” with its acoustic arches that amplify soft whispers into shouts.

Want to see more photos of the celebration? Tap the blue location text above. Photo by

Just outside of Solvang, in Central California, 50 ostriches eagerly await visitors day in and day out at Ostrichland. Ostrich are native to Africa, can run up to 45 miles per hour, and weigh between 250 and 350 pounds. The Browns, a husband and wife team, have run the unique farm for two decades. Visitors are invited to feed the bizarre creatures and can take home their fresh, giant ostrich eggs.
Want to see more photos of Ostrichland? Tap the blue location text above this image. Photo by
Today, chef & longtime Instagrammer  dropped by to say hello to the Instagram team! We love seeing Jamie document his food adventures on Instagram and we were all excited to meet him.

Each year in Scotland, thousands of men bearing torches parade through the streets on the last Tuesday of January to mark the end of the Yule Season. Though only officially begun in 1881, the Up Helly Aa day fire festivals have their roots in ancient Anglo Saxon rites. Revelers pay homage to this history by dressing in full costume and electing a Jarl to head the festivities. The Jarl and his committee lead the torch-bearers through the town to a replica of a Viking longship, which they set ablaze with the torches. After the burning, townspeople retire to local public halls for a night of dancing and performances. The Wednesday after is taken as a day of recovery before "Hop Night" when the festivities continue until morning. To view more photos, visit blog.instagram.com, search the  hashtag, or click the blue location link above. Photo by .

Over the course of the year, Southeast Asia's largest lake, the Tonlé Sap in Cambodia, can fluctuate from depths as low as two meters to as high as 14 meters. The inhabitants of the Tonlé Sap’s banks survive this ebb and flow by building floating villages. Their houses, churches, police departments and post offices are built on stilts, they navigate their neighborhoods in boats, and they construct elaborate traps to catch fish as the tide drains.
See Instagrammers' photos of these floating villages by tapping the blue location text above this image. Photo by

Over the weekend, Instagrammers around the world got together to take photos and share them on Instagram. We were excited to see photos posted from Vancouver (), Philadelphia (), Chicago (), Copenhagen (), Preroria (), Johannesburg (), Durban (), and Girona, Spain, where over 200 Instagrammers got together for ! Want to host your own InstaMeet or photo scavenger hunt? Be sure to check out blog.instagram.com for tips on how to organize a great event.

Who says it takes a brick-and-mortar store to get your treats into the hands of a hungry public? Through their Instagram account, , a yet-to-be-opened doughnut shop in Costa Mesa, California, has been keeping their fans up to date on the progress of their new store, sharing the location of their Sidecar doughnut-selling truck, and snapping candid photos of what's happening in the kitchen. If your Instagram feed could use a little sweetening, follow along at .

If you’re a "Where’s Waldo" fan, you’re going to love Andrew Knapp’s () Instagram photos. Somewhere in Andrew's Ontario landscapes, his border collie, Momo, is often hiding from view. Andrew uses the hashtag  in captions to encourage other Instagrammers to play along and spot Momo.

Andrew says the series started by chance. “Momo usually runs ahead of me when I’m tossing a stick for him, and it so happened that he ended up in a couple of the shots. I started hashtagging  and it all kind of pieced itself together!” Can you  in this photo? Be sure to follow  to see the whole series!

Over the weekend, the annual Wakakusa Yamayaki (山焼き), or 'mountain roast,' took place in Nara, Japan. A group of Buddhist monks starts the festival by carrying sacred fire to a shrine at the foot of Mount Wakakusa and igniting dead grass. A fire brigade stands by at all times, and onlookers from the city nearby are treated to a massive fireworks display as the hill catches fire. The tradition is over 400 years old, and it takes just under an hour for the fire to spread across the mountain.

Want to see more photos of Wakakusa Yamayaki? Tap the blue location text above this image. Photo by

Happy Monday! Are you ready for the ? This week, we meet Rusty, a husky with captivating blue eyes and a multitude of endearing expressions. Follow him at  if you need a little more arctic fluff in your Instagram feed!

On January 28, 1813, Jane Austen's publisher Thomas Egerton released her second novel, Pride and Prejudice. Austen finished writing the novel in 1797 under the title First Impressions, but after prospective publishers declined to even see the manuscript, she heavily edited the story over the following 14 years until Egerton bought it for £110 ($172 present-day USD). Today marks the beginning of festivals, conferences and Austen readathons that "Janeites" have planned throughout the year to celebrate the story of Elizabeth Bennet and Mr. Darcy's tumultuous courtship. Two centuries later, Pride and Prejudice remains one of the most-taught and best-loved classics in Western literature.

Tap the blue location text above this image for photos from the upcoming festivals. Photo by

In 2012, Berlin celebrated its 775th anniversary. Among the many festivities, several large open-air exhibits were constructed, including a beautiful walkable map of Berlin called City of Diversity in front of the largest church in the city. Though it's no longer on display, many visitors shared photographs of the exhibit on Instagram! View more photos on the Schlossplatz location page by tapping the blue text above this photo and visiting blog.instagram.com. Featured photo by .

Weekend Hashtag Project: 

The goal this weekend is to capture photographs of places blanketed with fog. Some tips about fog to get you started: it can accumulate very early in the morning or right after sunset when there is high humidity, and fog often makes an appearance over lakes, in forests, lowlands, valleys, and near the sea. Be sure to browse the Instagram account for San Francisco's famous fog, , for some inspiration!

PROJECT RULES: Please only add the hashtag to photos taken over this weekend and only submit your own photographs to the project. Any image taken then tagged over the weekend is eligible to be featured on the Instagram blog at blog.instagram.com on Monday morning! Featured photo by .

On Tuesday evening, a vacant warehouse in Chicago’s  neighborhood caught fire. It took more than 200 firefighters the entire night to bring the blaze under control. With Chicago facing some of the coldest temperatures of the season, the water used to battle the flames froze to the exterior of the building. The warehouse-turned-ice cube has attracted visitors from across the area, who have been documenting the uncommon sight through Instagram. To view more photos, visit blog.instagram.com, or click the blue location link above for the nearby Advertising Flag Company. Photo by .

Have you ever wondered what it would be like to drop everything, get in your car, and start a photographic exploration of the world? Full-time traveler Kevin Russ () did just that! He journeyed throughout the American West for an entire year and chased inspiration for his beautiful iPhone-only wildlife and nature photographs. Head on over to blog.instagram.com to to hear about how Kevin captures his photos, what inspires him, why he uses Instagram, and some amazing stories from behind the lens. Be sure to follow  for a look into his next great adventure!

Did you know we have a Suggested Users List full of great Instagrammers to discover? There, you'll find people like Simone Bramante (), an art director from Bologna, Italy, who takes incredible portraits like the one above. Visit your Profile tab and tap the gear icon, then tap Find & Invite Friends > Suggested Users to see them, or view the whole list at one time by browsing who this account () is following. The list is always changing, so be sure to check back often!

The Orlando Towers stand tall in Soweto, Johannesburg, an area that was once the center of popular resistance to apartheid. The two brightly decorated cooling towers were built in 1951 and decommission in 1998, but are popular today with local photographers and daredevils alike. One tower is a functioning billboard and the other displays the largest mural painting in South Africa. In addition to serving as public art, a platform connecting the two towers makes them a hotbed for bungee and BASE jumping. To see more photos, tap the blue location text above this image. Photo by

From Tower Bridge to the London Eye, London resident Lindsey Stopp () takes you on a grand tour of her city’s iconic sights from the seat of her beloved bicycle. Lindsey started snapping Instagram photos in May 2012 when she bought her first bike and London was alive with Olympic preparations. She takes her mobile photos on the move and edits them later on Instagram. “I cycle everywhere, everyday, and there’s always something that catches my eye…even when I think I won’t find a photo in an area I’ve been 100 times before, I always do.” Want to see more? Be sure to follow her on Instagram:

Today, an estimated 800,000 people crowded onto the National Mall to witness the swearing-in of President Barack Obama. The inauguration is the 57th in the United States' history and follows the November 6 reelection of Barack Obama, America's 44th President. View more photos at the ,  and  hashtags, and by clicking the blue location link above. Photo by .

Today, the world’s top surfers descend on Half Moon Bay, California, to compete in the Maverick’s Invitational big wave surf contest. For the first time since 2010, the Maverick's organizers have decided an incoming swell is strong enough for the competition to take place. Wave faces promise to be 30-40 feet and exceptionally powerful.

The beaches will be closed to spectators for their own safety, but you can get close to the action on Instagram. Be sure to follow  and  for updates from the competition, and stay tuned to Maverick’s competitors , , and  for an athlete’s perspective. You can also visit the Maverick’s Beach location page by tapping the blue location text above this image. Photo by .

picture_list.location: 両国国技館 (The Ryogoku Kokugikan Sumo Arena)
picture_list.caption: At Ryōgoku Kokugikan (両国国技館) in Tokyo, the first major sumo tournament of 2013 began today. The tournament lasts for 15 days with top sumo wrestlers, or rikishi, competing once each day. The goal for all rikishi is to end the tournament with a majority of wins, which ensures they advance to the next tournament in a yearlong series. Want to see more photos of the tournament as it unfolds? Tap the blue location text above this image. Photo by

Weekend Hashtag Project: 

Last weekend we asked you to look up, so it’s only natural that this weekend we ask you to capture photographs of what you see when you look down at your feet! Some tips to get you started: look for interesting textures and patterns on the ground like marble, wood or even fallen leaves. The beach can make an excellent backdrop for this prompt; and keep an eye out for street art displayed on concrete!

PROJECT RULES: Please only add the hashtag to photos taken over this weekend and only submit your own photographs to the project. Any image taken then tagged over the weekend is eligible to be featured on the Instagram blog at blog.instagram.com on Monday morning! Featured photo by .
This morning, Instagram's favorite  Chiweenie, , melted the hearts of millions with his appearance on the . Way to go, Tuna!

On January 12, 5,834 people turned out for a snowball fight in Seattle, Washington to set a new Guinness World Record. The battle, documented through the  Instagram feed and  hashtag, beat the old record of 5,347 set on January 22, 2010, in Taebaek City, South Korea. See more photos by browsing the  hashtag! Photo by .

In a remote part of Swedish Lapland, tucked away in a forest just south of the Arctic Circle, are the most stylish tree houses in the world. The Treehotel in Harads, Sweden, has five unique “treerooms,” each designed by one of Scandinavia’s leading architects with custom-designed furniture, lighting, and fabrics.

The idea behind the Treehotel is to create a space that gives people a chance to “experience nature amongst the tree-tops, while also providing a uniquely designed housing experience.” Want to see more? Check out photos Instagrammers have taken there by tapping the blue location text above this image. Photo by

Tommy Edison () has been blind since birth, but that hasn’t stopped him from sharing photographs of the world around him with Instagram. Tommy’s viral video, "How Blind People Use Instagram," explains exactly how a blind person takes photographs with the application. He’s also shared a few more details into his experience and process directly with us. "My favorite part has to be reading all the comments because I get to find out what the photo is. People will describe what they see in the picture and tell me if it’s a good angle, or if it’s too dark. It’s like a game to me—point, shoot, and wait to see what it is. It’s really interesting that people want to see what a blind person does with a camera."

Some say there’s no better way to explore America’s vast, diverse landscape than to drive through the heart of it. Joshua Works, his wife, Jessa, and their four-year-old son, Jack, are doing just that in an iconic 27-foot-long, 200-square-foot Airstream trailer.
The Works family () has been on the road full-time for nearly two years, traveling through 41 states, and Joshua says their trip has no end in sight: "We wanted to take some risks and see if we could create a lifestyle that meets more of our demands—regular contact with nature, greater cultural diversity, more time as a family—and throws out the things we disliked most—daily commutes, tedious household work, interminable daily routines. And we’d say that’s all been a success. There are definitely still challenges and compromises, but we encourage those who are interested and capable to consider full-time travel as a perfectly viable lifestyle." Be sure to go along for the ride by following their Instagram account , browsing their hashtags ( and  are two great ones), and exploring their Photo Map!

On the second Monday of every January, Japan observes Coming of Age Day (成人の日), meant to commemorate and celebrate young Japanese who turned 20—legal adult age—during the previous year. Made an official holiday in 1948, these ceremonies have existed for over 1200 years. Japanese men and women often don traditional clothing and attend events at local government offices in the morning before hosting parties and celebrating with friends and family later in the day. To see more colorful photos, browse the  hashtag. Photo by .
